Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC at Mississippi State University: Center for Environmental Sustainability through Insect Farming
Award.AbstractNarration:
Food demand from the growing human population is expected to increase 100% over the next 40 years; however, predicted growth in agriculture production will fail to meet demand by ~40%. The inability to meet future food demands places more pressure on the one billion individuals currently underfed and living in substandard conditions throughout the world. These limitations will manifest into amplified social pressures such as, but not limited to, increased rates of disease, demand for land and water resources, and a lack of agricultural entrepreneurship, which only further weakens the global economy. A sustainable method (i.e., practical and economical) for remediating agricultural waste, while producing high value protein is essential to the long-term health of ecosystems and agriculture. One solution is the utilization of insect farming to convert organic wastes, which will potentially produce alternate resources of monetary value for the farmer. Insect farming can produce enormous amounts of protein and lipids that can be used in a variety of commodity settings (e.g., feed production, compost, biofuels, human food in some cases). And this production of alternative protein sources is less environmentally straining than most currently used methods in terms of reduced land and water usage and reduced emissions.

The Center for Environmental Sustainability through Insect Farming (CESTIns) will be comprised of three sites (Texas A&M AgriLife Research [TAMU], Indiana University-Purdue University in Indianapolis [IUPUI], and Mississippi State University [MSU]), with each site specializing in a specific area of research. The purpose of the MSU site is to: 1) Investigate insect microbiomes to optimize, and to evaluate their utility for increased insect nutrition, nutrition as feed, and waste conversion; 2) Conduct experiments to determine effects of probiotic supplementation on insect nutrition, feed nutrition, and waste conversion; 3) Use classical and molecular microbiology to develop and implement management plans for quality assurance (prevention) and control (detection) of microbial pathogens. MSU will work with the other sites to integrate research thrusts across the three sites with IUPUI and TAMU focusing on genetics, insect biology, and engineering and feed trials, respectively. Further, all three sites will work with strains produced by Industry as well as strains developed internally as a means to optimize mass production. Laboratory and field-based experiments will also engage interdisciplinary expertise in microbiology, engineering, chemistry, food nutrition, physiology, and vertebrate biology with cutting edge technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The planning grant for the NSF Center for Insects as Food & Feed was held 17-19 September on the IUPUI campus in Indianapolis, Indiana. A mixer was held the evening of 17 September. Chef Joseph Yoon prepared heavy appetizers that included insects as an ingredient.  A total of 30 companies representing North America, Africa, Europe, and Asia were present. The purpose of the mixer was to allow for everyone to become acquainted with one another prior to the initiation of the conference the next day. IUPUI media relations was present and conducted interviews of attendees.

 

During day two of the event, an overview of the center structure was presented along with its purpose for the industry. There were 30 companies representing varies industry sectors including but not limited to: Insects as feed, insects as food, feed ingredient companies, and biotechnology.  Administrative representatives from each institution presented an overview of resources available for the Center once funded and established.  Ten research presentations (15 minutes each; 8 minutes for presentation, 5/2 minutes for discussion, and 2/5 minutes for entering information into LIFE forms) were given during day this session. These projects represented an overview of the research categories potentially of interest to industry. Topics included: 1) optimization and production of insects; 2) examples of feed trials for aquaculture and poultry; 3) quality assurance measures for the insects and the supply chain; 4) enhancements through microbiology and/or genetics/genomics; 5) understanding domestication genetics of insects; 6) use of insect by-products as fertilizer; 7) human perception of insects as food ingredients; and, 7) public relations and communication. Industry was asked to complete LIFE forms (electronic comment cards) at the conclusion of each presentation. Once presentations were concluded, a discussion reviewing the topics occurred. The purpose of the discussion was to refine, diversify, or exclude topics from center consideration. Researchers were asked to take information provided by industry and incorporate such materials into responses to industry comments provided through the LIFE forms.   Guest speaker Sonny Ramaswamy, former administrator of the United States Department of Agriculture National Institute of Food and Agriculture, presented an overview of needs for research of insects as food and feed during the lunch hour.  The end of the day’s activities included a poster session of expanded descriptions of each research presentation, as well as a hosted dinner where industry members, university representatives and NSF program officers continued discussions.

 

Day three was initiated with a review of LIFE forms for each project.  Industry were allowed to elaborate on each project, stating project strengths and weaknesses following group discussions. A closed door session ensued where industry communicated with NSF representatives with regards to the center concept. They were also allowed to “vote” for projects they would support once the center is formed. Projects receiving the highest votes included those concentration on: 1) life history trait/industrialization; 2) human perception of insect protein; 3) optimization using genetics/genomics and microbiology; and 4) other.  Those voting “Other” expressed interest in topics included but not limited to developing industry standards, animal welfare, insect disease, pets and hypoallerginicity as well as the development of a knowledge database available to members (including literature review and summarized metadata repositories).  A summary of industry votes was provided to academic teams for consideration when revising projects. Following the summary discussion, the meeting was concluded.

 Since the meeting has concluded, Site Directors have held several phone calls/teleconferences with both those in attendance and those who could not attend, and we have been soliciting letters of support for our Phase I proposal.
